title: Fort Union Trading Post National Historic Site: Fort Union 50th
body: Explore This Park    Learn About the Park     History & Culture     Fort Union 50th               Fort Union 50th       Fort Union ruled the Upper Missouri as an active fur trading post 1828-1867. Shortly after closing, the US Military scavenged building materials to expand Fort Buford. Thereafter the site it listed "in ruins" by historic maps.  By 1900, nothing of the "old post" remained but some surface depressions and exposed artifacts.  By the next century, Fort Union Trading Post has evolved to a 441-acre National Historic Site managed by the National Park Service. Check out the links below to learn the stories of how local support, in many forms, transformed an empty field into an 1851-era partial reconstruction that again looms over the Upper Missouri River.  Â    You're a Grand Old Flag(pole)
